Project Description  The anticipated overall rate of increase in power demand in the 
northern part of the country is expected to be 16.5% per annum 
over the period 2001–2010. In order to meet this load growth, the 
Government has decided to construct a 500-kilovolt (kV) ring 
main transmission system around the major load centers in the 
north covering Hanoi, Haiphong, and Quang Ninh. The proposed 
sector project is part of this expansion program. The Project has 
two major components—Part A: expansion and upgrading of the 
500 kV and 220 kV transmission systems, and Part B: upgrading 
and expansion of the supervisory control and data acquisition 
system, plus communications facilities at the north, central, and 
south  regional  centers  and  the  national  load  dispatch  center 
(NLDC) in Hanoi. 
   
Rationale  The proposed project will strengthen the northern power system 
of Viet Nam so as to enable power transmission with adequate 
reliability and quality from new plants under construction and 
additional  generating  capacity  programmed  over  the  next  5 
years.  Through  its  loan  covenants,  the  proposed  project  will 
further the ongoing power sector reforms to restructure Electricity 
of Vietnam (EVN) and thereby create a profitable and viable 
electricity supply industry in Viet Nam. 
   
Objectives  The  objectives  of  the  Project  are  to  (i) directly expand and 
strengthen EVN’s transmission system in the north to improve 
system  reliability  and  quality,  and  (ii) indirectly  improve  the 
efficiency of the power sector by promoting restructuring and 
commercialization of EVN. ADB’s programmed interventions in 
the sector during 2004–2007 will support the power sector reform 
efforts  aimed  at  establishing  a  “single-buyer”  power  market 
structure and transparent regulation of the sector by 2009. 
   
Cost Estimates  The  Project  is  estimated  to  cost  $273.6 million  inclusive  of 
physical  and  price  contingencies  and  financial  charges 
comprising a foreign exchange cost of $174.6 million and local 
currency cost of $99.0 million equivalent.

Risks and Assumptions  The  financial  and  economic  viability  of  the  proposed  project 
depends  on  the  implementation  of  the  other  components  of 
power  system  expansion  in  northern  Viet  Nam.  These  also 
include significant investments in new power generation capacity 
as  well  as  transmission  capacity  outside  the  scope  of  the 
proposed Project. The mobilizing of these investments requires 
concerted efforts by EVN and other public sector investors as 
well  as  the  private  sector  financing  and  in  successfully 
implementing these projects. It is expected that EVN and the 
Government will create the enabling environment by removing 
entry  barriers  for  private  sector  participation  (domestic  and 
foreign) through proposed power sector reforms. 
 
A key potential concern is the failure of the economy to continue 
achieving its assumed high economic growth rate of 7%. A lower 
rate of growth would reduce the rate of growth in electricity 
demand. However, the analysis of risks shows that the economic 
viability  of  the  investment  program  can  withstand  extreme 
adverse changes in anticipated economic growth, and in other 
key risk factors and assumptions.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Northern Power Transmission Sector Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Introduction 
 
2.  Pro-poor growth is a main component of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) strategy for 
reducing income poverty according to the Viet Nam Country Strategy and Program (CSP) 
(2002-2004). The CSP endorsed by the ADB Board in January 2002 emphasized the role of 
private sector development, agricultural productivity, financial sector reform, and small and 
medium  enterprise  development  to  achieve  such  growth.  The  Comprehensive  Poverty 
Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS)1 of Viet Nam aims to combine high and sustainable 
economic growth accompanied by targeted measures to create favorable opportunities for the 
poor to improve their living standards, as financed through the redistribution of the fruits of 
growth. This approach has proven successful in the last decade. The rapid economic growth of 
over  7.5%  has  contributed  to  bringing  down  the  proportion  of  the  population  below  the 
international poverty line from 58% in 1993 to less than 29% in 2002; the CPRGS target is for a 
further reduction to 24% by 2010.  
 
3.  The  critical  role  of  large-scale infrastructure in achieving poverty reduction through 
growth is underlined in a new chapter of the CPRGS approved by the Prime Minister of Viet 
Nam on 26 November 2003. The new chapter stresses the direct and indirect impact of 
infrastructure bottlenecks, increasing efficiency, and generating the growth and employment that 
will directly reduce poverty and indirectly allow redistributive programs to be financed.  ADB  
considers  ordinary capital resources (OCR) lending to  Viet Nam as a means of meeting the 
significant financing gap it faces in the infrastructure sector. The 2005-2006 Country Strategy 
and Program Update (CSPU) provided an initial response to these changed circumstances by 
developing an expanded OCR lending program focused on the power and transport sectors.  
 
4.  The power sector is a key sector for achieving the 7% average growth target up to 2010, 
which will require the share of the industry sector to increase from 37% in 2000 to 41% in 2010. 
The industry and services sectors are expected to maintain above average growth rates of 
10.5% and 8%, respectively, up to 2010 and this is forecast to result in a 13% growth rate over 
the same period in demand for electricity. As electricity is an underlying input for economic 
growth and job creation, any shortage of power will result in a slowing of the economy and 
underachievement in poverty reduction targets. 
 
5.  As a result of high sustainable economic growth and low initial consumption levels over 
the last decade, the demand for power has been growing at an average rate of 14% per annum. 
According to the Master Plan for Power Development for Viet Nam, 2001–2010 (Fifth Master 
Plan),2 annual ni vestments of $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion  are  required  to  increase  electricity 
supplies sufficiently to support the Government’s gross domestic product (GDP) projections.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Government Policies 
 
10.  The Government’s power sector policy and reform objectives were first articulated in the 
Power Sector Policy Statement issued by the Ministry of Industry on 1 December 1995. In 1997, 
the Government updated its Power Sector Policy Statement, outlining its objectives and strategy 
for the development of the power sector. In October 2004, the Government approved a new 
Power Sector Strategy (2004-2010).9 The policy objectives and reform strategy included in the 
2004 updated statement are to (i) provide electricity access to the national economy and the 
entire population of Viet Nam; (ii) increase the operating/technical efficiency of the electricity 
sector to optimize the use of scarce investment resources; (iii) ensure system reliability and 
quality of electricity supply; (iv) use country's primary energy sources such as hydropower, gas, 
oil, and coal for power generation; (v) gradually establish competitive domestic power market 
and encourage investments into the sector from non-EVN entities including private sector; 
(vi) promote regional power trading and cross-country transmission links; and (vii) set electricity 
prices at levels that promote investments in the sector. 
 
11.  To help achieve these policy objectives, the  2004 Power Sector  Strategy outlined a 
reform strategy that included developing a regulatory framework, adopting cost-based tariffs, 
promoting  private  sector  participation  in  the  supply  of  power,  increasing  rural  access  to 
electricity,  powergrids,  and  undertaking  demand-side  management.  The  Government’s 
structural  reform  objective  is  to  transform  the  power  sector  enterprises  into  efficient 
commercially run entities that are financially strong and creditworthy, and have management 
autonomy in their operations. The key strategy includes  (i) corporatizing the EVN-owned power 
plants, (ii) developing efficient pricing and contractual relationships between the transmission 
network  businesses  and  the  generation  stations  on  the  system,  (iii) converting  the  power 
companies (i.e., the seven distribution companies) into limited liability companies that have true 
financial and management autonomy, (iv) equitizing (i.e., partially divesting) power plants and

12.  The objective of legal and regulatory reform in the strategy is to form a consistent legal 
framework to facilitate commercial operations and government oversight of the sector. The key 
steps include (i) promulgating an Electricity Law; (ii) developing supporting secondary legislation 
to the Electricity Law to address (a) the scope and structure of the regulatory agency, (b) 
procedures for tariff setting and regulation, and (c) administrative regulations and standards; 
and (iii) preparing a grid code for interconnection and operating standards between generation 
entities and the transmission entities. 
 
13.  The electricity pricing objective is to use cost-based principles to set retail prices so as to 
ensure financial viability and promote efficient use of electricity, and efficient internal transfer 
prices to motivate the power companies to operate efficiently and purchase power economically. 
Although the prevailing average tariff is set at a level below the estimated long-run marginal cost, 
the tariffs are adequate to meet the financial obligations of the sector and to generate cash flows 
to meet an adequate share of the new investments. However, with increasing financing needs of 
the sector and expected returns on investments by private investors in the sector, the Government 
is committed to undertaking appropriate measures, including tariff adjustments, to ensure the 
financial viability of the sector as captured by prudential financial covenants. It is expected that 
through these tariff adjustments, the tariff will eventually approach the long-run marginal cost.

  3.  Asian Development Bank Sector Strategy 
 
16.  In accordance with ADB’s energy policy and overarching goal of poverty reduction, 
ADB’s strategy for the power sector of Viet Nam, as articulated in the 2004 CSPU (2005-2006), 
is to realize the following objectives: (i) ensure stable power supply for economic activity through 
financing  and  implementation  of  needed  power  sector  infrastructure  projects  including 
transmission, distribution, and generation (hydroelectric and thermal). Investments in power 
generation would complement private sector investments and would be structured in a manner 
to fill the investment gap in power generation after taking into account private sector capability 
or interest to meet the overall investment requirement of the power sector; (ii) promote financial 
and fiscal sustainability by unbundling EVN, into generation, transmission, and distribution 
companies  that  can  operate  as  commercially  viable  and  financially  independent  entities; 
(iii) create an enabling environment for private sector participation in a competitive power 
market in Viet Nam; (iv) encourage expansion of rural electrification subsystems and the use of 
renewable energy sources for power generation; and (v) encourage the transfer of power in the

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objectives 
22.  The  objectives  of  the  Project  are  to  (i) directly  expand  and  strengthen  EVN’s 
transmission system in the north to improve system reliability and quality, and (ii) indirectly 
improve the efficiency of the power sector by promoting restructuring and commercialization of 
EVN.  The  Project  and  the  subsequent  ADB  interventions  programmed  during  the 
implementation period of the Project will support the power sector reform efforts by ensuring 
that EVN’s generation units are corporatized/equitized and in establishing of a single-buyer 
power  market  with  transparent  regulation  of  the  sector  in  2009.  The  establishment  of  a 
transparent regulatory mechanism would also improve the private sector investment climate. 
 
23.  The Government’s sector policy and financing needs of the sector, and the capacity of 
EVN to implement the sector development program have been assessed and found to be 
acceptable and consistent with ADB’s sector policy and ADB’s requirements and procedures 
applicable to sector loans. Although the Project does not finance any sector restructuring 
assistance directly, provisions have been made in the 2004 CSPU for advisory TA in 2005 to 
improve the capability of EVN in meeting the restructuring challenge that lies ahead of it. Hence, 
the Project is structured as a sector loan consisting of two main components and a subset of 
about 24 subprojects, half of which have been appraised and the other half are to be appraised 
during the implementation phase.

8 
 
B.  Components and Outputs 
1.  Infrastructure Component 
 
24.  Due to the need to strengthen the northern transmission network to enable transmission 
(with adequate reliability and quality) of power from additional generating capacity programmed 
over the next 5 years, the Government has requested that the Project focus on subprojects in 
the north of the country. These subprojects would be undertaken during a 5-year period from 
2005. The Project has two major components—Part A: expansion and upgrading of the 500 kV 
and 220 kV transmission systems to transfer additional power to improve system reliability and 
enhance the efficient utilization of existing and new power plants, and Part B: upgrading and 
expansion  of  the  supervisory  control  and  data  acquisition  (SCADA)  system  through  the 
provision of remote terminal units (RTUs)  for substations and power plants, software and 
hardware upgrades to national regional load dispatch centers, and communications facilities 
linking three regional load dispatch centers (north, central, and south), and NLDC in Hanoi with 
the  RTUs  in  substations  and  power  stations.  This  will  improve  load  dispatch,  system 
performance, and system reliability. The candidate subprojects are described briefly in Appendix 
4. 
 
  2.  Technical Justification and Criteria for Subproject Selection 
 
25.  The justification  of  each  subproject  is  supported  by  load-flow  and  stability  studies, 
evaluation of alternatives, detailed design, cost estimates, financial and economic analyses, 
summary initial examination of environmental and social issues, and implementation schedules. 
Twenty  four  subprojects  (out  of  a  total  number  of  410  candidate  500 kV  and  220 kV 
transmission subprojects) were selected from EVN's Fifth Master Plan for support under this 
loan. Subprojects were selected on the basis of (i) technical suitability and (ii) environmental 
considerations and social soundness conforming to relevant ADB guidelines. The financial and 
economic internal rates of return (FIRR, EIRR) for individual subprojects were not calculated as 
they were part of EVN's overall investment over the period 2004–2010 for which a detailed 
financial and economic analysis has been done. Since all the identified subprojects are based 
on well-proven technology and are generally within EVN's implementation capability, there are 
no significant technical or engineering risks. The planning and implementation capability of EVN 
has been reviewed and found to be satisfactory. 
 
26.  To date, 12 subprojects have been appraised with the remaining 12 will be appraised 
during implementation. The criteria for selection of the subprojects, and any other subproject not 
identified at appraisal but still part of the Fifth Master Plan, or subsequent revision thereof, will 
require EVN to produce (i) a technical feasibility study for each subproject, (ii) a resettlement 
action plan (RAP), and (iii) an environment assessment plan (EAP). The technical feasibility 
study will include a detailed engineering design of the subproject, including alternatives and 
indication  that  this  is  the  least-cost  solution,  cost  estimates,  procurement  packaging,  and 
implementation schedule. Further, the RAP and EAP of proposed subprojects must meet the 
requirements of the Resettlement Framework (Supplementary Appendix B) and the criteria for 
environmental requirements as given in the initial environmental examination (IEE). For each 
subproject to be appraised, EVN will need to submit an appraisal report to ADB for approval. 
Appendix 5 provides the format for submission of the subproject appraisal report. Proposed 
subprojects that do not meet the above requirements will not be approved for inclusion in the 
Project.

  3.  Resettlement 
 
27.  The  Project  will  require  land  acquisition  for  the  construction  and  extension  of 
substations, and of any necessary access roads as well as  towers and foundations for the 
transmission lines. For the first batch of  subprojects appraised,it was identified that a total of 
901 households (2,474 people) will be affected by land acquisition. Of these, 357 households 
(825 people) will be severely affected and 544 households (1,649 people) will be marginally 
affected. Two hundred four households will have to move from their houses (but should be able 
to rebuild on their remaining plot of land). The total land to be permanently acquired will be 
243,493 hectares, which will severely affect 113 households (104 losing agricultural land and 
nine losing forestry land). Another 909,561 hectares of land will be acquired for temporary use 
during the construction phase. Only two small businesses are affected, and even then, only 
marginally. Except for land required for towers, the land within the right-of-way can continue to 
be  used  for  agricultural  purposes.  Compensation  for  all  lost  assets  will  be  provided  at 
replacement cost at current market value, and socioeconomic rehabilitation measures will be 
provided to ensure that affected people will be at least as well off as they would have been in 
the absence of the Project. The poorest affected and vulnerable affected people will be assisted 
to improve their socioeconomic status. 
 
28.  A RAP has been prepared for the following project components: (i) construction of 
151.59 km  of  500 kV  double-circuit  transmission  line  from  Quang  Ninh  to  Thuong  Tin, 
(ii) construction of one 500 kV substation at Quang Ninh and one 220 kV substation at Van Tri, 
and (iii) expansion of one 500 kV substation at Thuong Tinh in Ha Tay province and one 220 kV 
substation  at  Vat  Cach  in  Haiphong  province.  A  resettlement  policy  framework  has  been 
prepared to guide NPPMB in addressing resettlement issues related to those components and 
subprojects for which no feasibility study has yet been undertaken but which are expected to 
form part of the Project. The Summary Resettlement Plan and Framework is attached as 
Appendix  6  and  the  full  Resettlement  Action  Plan  and  Resettlement  Framework  are  in 
Supplementary Appendixes A and B, respectively. 
 
  4.  Capacity Building 
 
29.  NPPMB staff assigned to the Project does not have adequate experience in involuntary 
resettlement. NPPMB and its local consultants will be assisted, therefore, to strengthen their 
capacity  for  resettlement  planning,  implementation,  and  monitoring.  An  international  and 
domestic resettlement consultant will be recruited to provide formal and on-the-job training 
during project implementation and to guide and supervise preparation, implementation, and 
monitoring of the RAPs. 
 
C.  Special Features 
30.  Since its creation in 1995, EVN's financial performance has been reasonable and it has 
consistently made a profit. This performance has mainly been attributed to  the operational 
efficiency  gains  EVN  has  achieved  coupled  with  the  rapid  expansion  of  the  Vietnamese 
economy as a whole, resulting in a large increase in demand for electricity. Electricity demand 
has increased at a faster rate than GDP, and EVN has taken advantage of this fact. However, in 
order to satisfy future demand resulting from sustained economic growth, EVN will need to 
make considerable investments in generation, transmission, and distribution. As it continues to 
increase its indebtedness at a rapid pace, this rate of expansion could have a significant impact 
on financial performance.

10 
31.  Despite  its  ambitious  capital  expansion  program,  it  appears  EVN  can  maintain  its 
financial viability, provided that tariff increases are implemented as  projected and additional 
financial income from equitization is realized. Although EVN has already achieved significant 
efficiency  improvements  (i.e.,  system  losses  at  12.8%  and  receivables  of  20  days),  it  is 
expected that further gains will be realized, especially in unit cost of power generation, due to 
the introduction of competition in power generation. Financial performance covenants have 
been set on this basis to ensure financial viability while at the same time providing EVN with 
enough financial flexibility to make the necessary adjustments in the short term. As shown in 
Appendix  7,  compliance  of  the  financial  covenants  is  projected  over  the  forecast  period. 
However, should additional income not materialize from equitization or revenue not grow in line 
with these assumptions, further increases in retail tariffs may be required to maintain covenant 
compliance.  
 
32.  EVN’s competence as an EA has been demonstrated by its successful implementation 
of two World Bank loans and the two ADB loans, which has supported PC 1, PC 2, and PC 3. A 
sector loan is therefore considered appropriate to finance a portion of EVN’s investments over 
the next 5 years. Through the sector loan approach, ADB can support EVN to improve power 
system performance and facilitate further sector reform. A sector loan approach will internalize 
the process of choosing subprojects that meet technical, financial, economic, environmental, 
and social criteria appropriate to modernizing the power subsector. The sector loan approach 
will also provide EVN with sufficient flexibility to optimally utilize the cofinancing assistance 
provided by Agence Française de Développement (AFD).

F.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Project Management 
36.  The Project will be implemented as a sector loan and  additional subprojects will be 
introduced during the implementation stage. The Government has agreed to delegate the 
authority for approving subprojects to EVN and, once approved, these subprojects would be 
submitted to ADB for financing under the Project. Implementation of the Project for the 500 kV 
and  220 kV  substations  and  transmission  lines  will  be  the  responsibility  of  NPPMB,  and 
implementation of the load dispatch facilities upgrade will be the responsibility of NLDC, in their 
capacity  of  implementing  agencies.  Adequately  staffed  project  offices  have  already  been 
established in Hanoi headquarters of NPPMB and NLDC for supervision of the Project. An 
international consultant, in association with suitably qualified domestic consultants, will assist 
NPPMB with resettlement planning, implementation, and internal monitoring. Supervision of 
contracts will be carried out by staff of the respective implementing agencies.  
 
2.  Implementation Schedule 
37.  Project  implementation  will  start  in  2004  with  the  recruitment  of  consultants.  Bid 
documents for international competitive bidding (ICB) packages will be prepared concurrently 
with technical design to allow bid documents to be approved quickly. Delivery of equipment will 
be  phased  to  suit  NPPMB’s  and  NLDC’s  storage  capacities  and  capability  of  erection 
contractors. The Project is expected to be completed by June 2009, 6 months prior to the 
anticipated  loan  closing  of  December  2009.  The  implementation  schedule  is  shown  in 
Appendix 9.

the  ADB  Guidelines  for  Procurement.  Advance  action  for  procurement  of  equipment  was 
requested by the Government and approved by ADB in the interest of early implementation of 
the  Project.  The  Government  authorities  were  informed  that  ADB’s  approval  of  advance 
procurement action would not in any way commit ADB to approve the Project subsequently or to 
finance the costs incurred. Supply of materials and services to be procured from international

7.  Project Performance Monitoring and Evaluation 
43.  NPPMB and NLDC will prepare separate progress reports for their respective investment 
components and submit them to ADB on a quarterly basis. The reports will provide a narrative

difficulties encountered, performance of the project implementation consultants, and the work to 
be carried out in the next period. The progress reports will also include a summary financial

44.  A midterm review to be carried out 2 to 3 years after loan effectiveness will focus on the

status of EVN. Representatives of ADB, EVN, and the cofinancier, AFD, will take part in the 
review. The review will allow for any necessary midcourse corrections to ensure successful 
project implementation and achievement of objectives. 
 
IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
45.  The  proposed  sector  loan  comprises  individual  subprojects,  including  a  500 kV 
transmission line and a series of substations, included in the Government’s power sector 
investment  program  to  meet  growing  electricity  demand  in  the  northern  region.  As  these 
individual subprojects are not stand-alone investments, the economic and financial analyses

15 
were conducted using a macro time-slice approach for the entire northern region investment 
program. The investment program analyzed the period 2004 to 2010 and is based on a least-
cost expansion plan in generation and transmission. 
46.  The financial and economic viability was examined on the basis of comparing the costs 
and benefits of meeting demand growth by the investment program with a without-investment 
program scenario where demand would not be met. The period of the investment program 
defines all associated costs and benefits of meeting demand growth. The analysis runs out to 
2030 but with investments halting in 2010. The without-investments program scenario assumes 
that there will be no investments in the north beyond 2004 but accounts for the possibility of 
meeting demand beyond 2004 from spare capacity.  This case represents the costs of not 
implementing the investment program and accounts for the subsequent impact on the system. 
The without-investment scenario assumes that EVN will keep connecting consumers and meet 
demand until it either runs out of generation capacity or puts stress on the transmission system. 
To determine the costs associated with the without-investment case, Wien Automatic System 
Planning (WASP) analysis was carried out for generation, and load-flow studies were conducted 
for the transmission system, on the assumption that the expansion program in the northern 
region  would  be  frozen.  The  investment  program  for  the  central  and  southern  regions  is 
assumed to be continued. The consequences include increased operation and maintenance 
costs, fuel cost increases as generation plants with a higher dispatch cost are forced to operate 
for longer hours, and the economic costs of unserved energy for consumers. 
 
A.  Financial Analysis 
 
47.  The analysis was made over the period from 2004–2030 when power plants built during 
2004–2010 would end their useful economic life. The financial evaluation of the investment 
program was undertaken in real terms using constant 2004 prices. The cost estimates and 
financial projections in nominal terms were converted to real terms by adjusting for the projected 
effects  of  foreign  and  domestic  inflation  and  currency  fluctuations.  Incremental  costs  and 
benefits attributable to the investment program were derived by evaluating the financial position 
of EVN under with- and without-project scenarios. The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) for 
the investment program, computed on an after-tax basis, is 12.8%. This compares favorably 
with the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) of EVN for the period under consideration, 
also computed on an after-tax basis, of 6.9%. When discounted at WACC, the proposed 
investment program has a net present value (NPV) of D43.2 trillion. The investment program is 
considered both financially viable and sustainable. Sensitivity and risk analysis indicate that the 
FIRR  for  each  component  and  the  investment  program  overall  are  robust  under  adverse 
conditions. The analysis is explained in Appendix 12. 
 
B.  Economic Analysis 
 
48.  The  economic  viability  of  the  investment  program  was  analyzed  on  the  basis  of 
incremental costs and benefits as compared to the without-investment scenario. The economic 
benefits of meeting incremental electricity demands were valued on the basis of willingness to 
pay and end-consumer tariffs for each consumer category. A conversion factor of 0.91 was 
applied to the consumer surplus to account for exchange rate distortions. The cost of unserved 
energy for residential poor and nonpoor consumers was valued in terms of forgone value of 
leisure resulting from the load shedding that would occur in the without-investment scenario. 
The cost of unserved energy for nonresidential consumers was evaluated at the cost of self-
generation. Benefits associated with increased operation and maintenance and fuel costs,

16 
which would result from the without-investment case, are reflected as cost reductions for the 
investment scenario.  
 
49.  Incremental  costs  of  the  investment  program  were  evaluated  in  terms  of  capital 
expenditures in generation, load dispatch, transmission, and distribution to end-consumers and 
the cost of energy purchase from independent power producers (IPPs). The conversion factor 
was  applied  to  nontraded  cost  elements  to  account  for  economic  distortions  in  the  local 
economy. It is assumed that the connection of new consumers would remain part of government 
policy and the connections would be the same in the with- and without-project cases, but with 
poorer quality of service.  
 
50.  The economic analysis is summarized in Table A13.3 of Appendix 13. All costs and 
benefits were discounted by a social discount factor of 12%. This shows that the investment 
program yields an EIRR of 40%. A sensitivity analysis was carried out with respect to key risks 
and assumptions. The result shows that the investment program is economically worthwhile 
even under combined extreme adverse conditions. The risk analysis shows that the risk of 
project failure is negligible. 
 
C.  Poverty Analysis 
 
51.  The poverty analysis undertaken for the Project was conducted to identify issues and 
assess impacts at the sector level, since it was difficult to identify specific end-consumers. The 
share of households connected to the grid is 86% and the majority of the poor are connected. 
Connection rates in the project areas range from 75% to 95%. These high connection rates 
imply that investments made in transmission will have economy-wide and direct benefits to poor 
end-consumers in terms of improving quality both of supply and of electricity services. Improved 
quality of services will reduce the cost of repair and repurchase of appliances and improve the 
quality of lighting. Increased quality of supply implies substantial welfare impacts for poor 
households. From the overall economy perspective, these welfare impacts may be small (due to 
the small consumption levels of the poor). However, from the household perspective a reduction 
in electricity expenditure and increased value of leisure are substantial. Reduced electricity 
expenditure releases household funds for food, health, and education expenditures. Most new 
residential consumers are expected to be poor. 
 
52.  The majority of benefits to the poor are expected to take place through increasing 
demand for labor resulting from improved services to industrial and commercial sectors in urban 
and semi-urban areas. Analysis indicates that these sectors will grow substantially in the 
medium term. Remittances from migrant labor will increase welfare and reduce vulnerability of 
rural households. The poverty analysis is provided in Appendix 14. 
 
D.  Impacts 
 
53.  The Project will cause significant involuntary resettlement, including paddy land for two 
substations and forestland for one, and houses and trees that must be removed from the 
transmission line right-of-way. Impact has been minimized by routing the transmission line away 
from built-up areas. Transmission line rights-of-way will be cleared permanently of structures 
and trees, but only the small areas under each tower and pole will be permanently acquired. 
The rest of the right-of-way will remain the property of the current landowner, who will be able to 
maintain its current use. Transmission line alignments determined during the feasibility study will 
be fine-tuned during detailed design and finalized during project implementation. Adequate

17 
compensation, relocation assistance, and income restoration measures have been designed to 
restore lost incomes and living standards. 
 
54.  Approximately 7% of the population surveyed during the socioeconomic survey was 
found  to  be  from  ethnic  minorities.  These  households  were  no  poorer  than  the  average 
household in the project area and more often than not, they were found to be better off. They 
were, like the majority of the population in this area, working in the agriculture sector and 
appeared to be completely integrated into the life of the rest of their respective communities. Of 
the affected households, 15 were from ethnic minorities and they all live in Quang Ninh 
province. The majority (12) lives in Uong Bi town and is from the Dao and Tay groups. A further 
three households live in Thong Nhat commune and are from the San Diu group. The Project is 
not expected to have any effect specific to these groups other than land acquisition, which is to 
be mitigated by the actions proposed in the RAP. In preparing for further subprojects, attention 
will be given specifically to assess the impacts on any minority groups likely to be affected. 
 
55.  The Project has been assessed as environmental category B. An IEE for the sample 
subprojects  is  provided  as  Supplementary  Appendix  C.  A  separate  section  on  candidate 
subproject  environmental  assessment  and  review  procedures,  including  the  environmental 
selection criteria, is included in the IEE. The sample substations and transmission line will not 
be located in or traverse any environmentally sensitive areas. Unavoidable impacts entailed 
from land take will occur at the two new substation sites but the anticipated impacts are 
considered  manageable  with  adequate  mitigation  measures.  The  IEE  provides  an 
environmental management plan (EMP) to reflect best practices, which will ensure that the 
impacts are adequately monitored and mitigated by the contractors. The EMP will be developed 
during  the  detailed  design  phase  and  will  be  implemented  by  the  contractors  under  the 
supervision  of  EVN  during  construction.  Institutional  arrangements  for  conducting  and 
monitoring the EMP are also provided in detail in the IEE. A series of public consultations on 
project-related environmental issues have been carried out in each province and will continue 
into the implementation phase of the Project.  
 
E.  Risks 
 
56.  Compensation, resettlement, and income restoration measures may not be delivered as 
agreed, thereby impoverishing affected people and delaying commencement of civil works. 
NPPMB will have specialists to assist in implementing the RAPs and NPPMB will engage an 
independent monitoring organization. 
 
57.  The  financial  and  economic  viability  of  the  proposed  project  depends  on  the 
implementation of the other components of the power system’s expansion in northern Viet Nam. 
These include significant investments in new power generation capacity as well as transmission 
capacity outside the scope of the proposed Project. This requires concerted efforts by EVN and 
other  public  sector  investors  as  well  as  the  private  sector  in  mobilizing  financing  and 
successfully implementing these projects. It is expected that EVN and the Government will 
create  the  enabling  environment  by  removing  entry  barriers  for  third  parties  through  the 
proposed power sector reforms. 
 
58.  The  financial  projections  of  EVN  have  been  prepared  on  the  assumption  that  (i) 
operational  efficiency  gains,  (ii)  proceeds  from  equitization,  and  (iii)  tariff  increases  are 
implemented  in  a  timely  manner  to  ensure  EVN’s  compliance  with  prudential  financial 
covenants. If the underlying assumptions relating to fuel cost, cost of purchase power from 
IPPs, and shift in the consumer mix deteriorate from the assumed values, then the required tariff

18 
increases  would  have  to  be  adjusted.  The  sensitivity  of  financial  ratios  used  as  financial 
covenants to the adverse movements of these assumptions were assessed and included in 
Appendix 8. This is especially important in the context of the proposed reforms with the 
introduction of limited competition in power generation under a single-buyer market structure. 
The setting up of a regulatory body under the proposed Electricity Law with powers to set tariffs 
on sound economic and financial grounds in a transparent manner will significantly mitigate this 
risk (Appendix 1). 
 
59.  It has been assumed that there will be significant private investments both in new 
projects as well as in acquiring EVN-owned power plants (i.e., equitization). The financial 
proceeds from selling equity stakes also make a significant contribution to EVN’s cash flows. As 
the power market in Viet Nam is relatively underdeveloped, the private sector must be willing to 
take the market and regulatory risks that may arise in such a market.  
 
60.  A key potential concern is the assumption of continued high economic growth of 7%. A 
lower rate of growth would reduce the rate of growth in electricity demand. However, the 
analysis of risks shows that economic viability of the investment program withstands extreme 
adverse changes in anticipated economic growth, and in other key risk factors and assumptions.

C.  Policy Framework and Entitlements 
 
4.  The  policy  framework  and  entitlements  of  the  Project  have  been  based  upon 
Vietnamese legislation, the Policy on Involuntary Resettlement (1995) of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB), and ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development (1998). The Government’s policy 
and legal framework toward resettlement are moving much closer  toward the principles of 
ADB’s policy. However, provisions and principles adopted in the RAP and RF for the Project 
supersede the provisions of the relevant decrees currently in force in Viet Nam wherever there 
is a discrepancy. 
 
D.  Project Principles 
 
5.  The following basic principles have been adopted for the Project: 
 
(i)  The principal objective of the RAP and RF is to ensure that the people affected 
by the Project should be at least as well off as, if not better off than, they would 
have been without the Project. Project-affected people should at least be able to 
maintain and preferably improve their standard of living and quality of life. 
(ii)  The populations affected by the Project are defined as those who may stand to 
lose, as a consequence of the Project, all or part of physical and nonphysical 
assets, including homes, homesteads, productive lands, commercial properties, 
tenancy,  income-earning  opportunities,  social  and  cultural  activities  and 
relationships, as well as other losses that may be identified during the process of 
resettlement planning. 
(iii)  Involuntary resettlement will be avoided or minimized by identifying possible 
alternative project designs and appropriate social, economic, operational, and 
engineering solutions that have the least impact on the population in the project 
area. 
(iv)  Neither  lack  of  legal  rights  to  the  assets  lost,  tenure  status,  nor  social  or 
economic  status  will  bar  the  affected  person  from  entitlement  to  the 
compensation and rehabilitation objectives and measures outlined in the RAP. 
(v)  The cut-off date for eligibility for compensation for physical assets affected by 
project  activities  such  as  the  construction  of  the  transmission  line,  towers, 
construction of the substations and construction of roads will be the date of 
completion of the detailed measurement survey and census after the detailed 
design has been completed for these components. 
(vi)  All project-affected people will be entitled to be compensated at replacement cost 
at current market value for affected assets, incomes and businesses; all severely 
affected project-affected people will also be provided with transitional assistance 
and income restoration and other rehabilitation assistance which will be sufficient 
to improve or at least restore their preproject living standards, income levels, and 
productive capacity. 
(vii)  After the detailed design has been completed for each component, a census and 
socioeconomic survey will be conducted as the basis for resettlement planning 
and RAP preparation and a detailed measurement survey will be carried out as a 
basis for compensation. 
(viii)  In the event of any population relocation, efforts will be made for existing social 
and cultural institutions of the people who are being resettled to be maintained to 
the greatest extent possible. 
(ix)  Preparation of RAPs, as part of subproject preparation and implementation, is to 
be  carried  out  with  the  full  participation  of  affected  people,  as  well  as

FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Project involves a number of subprojects consisting of augmentation of the existing 
transmission system at 500-kilovolt (kV) and 220 kV voltage levels and upgrading of the national 
load dispatch center. As these individual subprojects are not stand-alone investments and 
would not yield benefits if considered in isolation, the financial analysis was conducted using a 
time-slice approach for the entire northern region investment program. Hence the financial 
viability of the overall investment program in northern Viet Nam during the period 2004–2010, of 
which the subprojects to be financed under the project form part, has been assessed. The 
weighted average cost of capital (WACC) is also calculated for the overall investment program 
in northern Viet Nam to be financed by Electricity of Vietnam (EVN) and was compared with the 
financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  to  ascertain  the  financial  viability  of  the  investment 
program. The sensitivity of the FIRR to adverse movements in the underlying assumptions was 
also  assessed.  Based  on  this  analysis,  the  investment  program  in  northern  Viet  Nam  is 
financially viable. 
 
B.  Methodology 
 
2.  The financial analysis is carried out in a manner consistent with the assumptions in the 
economic  analysis.  The  sales  forecast  and  the  without-investment  case  described  in  the 
economic analysis are used for the purpose of evaluating the financial benefits attributable to 
the investment program during 2004–2010. The financial cost of total system failure due to 
noninvestment in north Viet Nam under the without-investment case, which is likely to happen 
after 2007, has also not been considered in the financial analysis. 
 
3.  The revenues under the with-investment case are frozen when the system capacity 
installed during 2004–2010 is fully utilized. The incremental financial benefits attributable to the 
investment program consist of the difference between cash flows under the with-investment 
case and the without-investment case. They are: 
 
(i)  the incremental sales over and above the curtailed sales under the without-
investment case; 
(ii)  savings on transmission losses compared with the without-investment case due 
to higher energy flows from south to north under without-investment case; and 
(iii)  the difference in generation cost between the two scenarios. The plant dispatch 
under the without-investment case is suboptimal and results in higher generation 
cost  on  a  per  unit,  i.e.,  per  kilowatt-hour  (kWh),  basis.  However,  the  total 
generation cost under the with-investment case would be more than the without-
investment case due to higher plant output to meet the higher demand.

6.  The  economic  viability  of  the  investment  program  was  examined  on  the  basis  of

7.  The  without-investment  scenario  assumes  that  there  will  be  no  investments  in

constrained by capacity available prior to 2004 but accounts for the possibility of meeting

have several direct consequences: 
 
(i)  losses in the northern region will rise. This is caused by the load growth requiring a 
higher current to go through the existing system; 
(ii)  the fuel cost increases as generation plants with a higher dispatch cost are forced to 
operate for longer hours; and 
(iii)  increasing levels of unserved energy. 
 
8.  With the investment program, the demand constraint will occur at a later period and at 
higher levels. Associated with the different demand levels in the with- and without-investment 
cases are capital expenditure, fuel, and operation and maintenance costs. Generation costs are 
based on the Fifth Master Plan Adjustment File (MP5 AF) and on estimates derived from the 
WASP III analysis. Transmission costs for 500 kV and 200 kV and distribution costs (110 kV 
and below) are based on the MP5 AF. These costs were revised to include resettlement costs 
and load dispatch cost. Interest during construction (IDC), taxes, and duties were removed from

9.  The  quantified  economic  benefits  associated  with  the  with-investment  case  include 
(i) cost savings resulting from higher fuel costs of meeting demand in the without-investment 
case, (ii) increased sales (since the load forecast will be severely constrained in the without-

10.  The approach taken to evaluate the benefits associated with incremental demand was to 
determine the area under the demand curve as the measure of willingness to pay (WTP) for 
each consumer group. This area is determined by taking two extreme points, where the first 
point represents the present tariff and the revealed consumption  at this tariff. The second 
extreme point represents the maximum price that consumers would be willing to pay for 
electricity. At prices higher than the maximum, consumers would avoid consuming electricity as 
the benefits would be less than the costs. The maximum price is determined by considering the 
value added by electricity consumption. The levels of electricity consumption at the maximum 
price  are  calculated  by  ensuring  equilibrium  between  cost  of  supply  and  the  benefits  of 
consumption.  
 
11.  For the domestic sector it is assumed that consumers have a choice between leisure 
and work where people would work up to the point where the marginal wage rate is equal to the 
marginal value of leisure. With electricity, the value of leisure increases. Thus, the value of 
electricity will be the loss of value, or welfare, of leisure caused by outage. For nondomestic 
consumers it is assumed that production ceases if there is no electricity. Thus, consumers 
would be willing to pay the amount up to the value added to avoid outage. Beyond this value, 
the costs exceed the benefits. Thus, the value of lost electricity is the lost output caused by 
outage, where output for each sector is taken to be sector gross domestic product. Thus, the 
cost to consumers of unserved energy represents the price they would be willing to pay to avoid 
outage. However, since nondomestic consumers would not be willing to pay more than it would 
cost to run an isolated generator, an upper bound is set at the cost of self-generation. The 
benefits  of  the  investment  program  associated  with  a  reduction  of  unserved  energy  are 
evaluated at the cost of unserved energy (COUE) for each consumer category. 
 
12.  Benefits associated with incremental demand are evaluated using a consumer surplus 
measure that reflects how much better off the consumers would be as a result of the price 
change in electricity. The consumer surplus measure reflects the change in money income 
resulting from the price change that would be needed to leave the consumer equally well off as 
compared to before the price change. This compensating welfare measure is used to define the 
WTP for each consumer category. The calculated WTPs were adjusted by the conversion factor 
since they were estimated at the official US$ exchange rate. The WTP and COUE by consumer 
category  are  shown  in  Table A13.2  and  the  details  of  the  calculations  are  presented  in 
Supplementary Appendix D.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Viet Nam: 
 
Viet Nam has made remarkable progress in providing electricity services to the population.  This is a key objective in 
the Government’s strategy to reduce poverty and vulnerability. The share of households with access to electricity 
increased from 49% in 1992 to 86% in 2002. Demand for electricity has increased substantially in the last decade with 
increasing incomes and reduced poverty. This has increased household affordability of appliances and electricity 
services. However, annual per capita consumption remains among the lowest in Asia at about 321 kilowatt-hours 
(kWh). Utilization of households is even lower, about 158 kWh per year or 13 kWh per month. 
 
Reliable and good quality of electricity supply is key for economic growth and poverty reduction. Electricity supply 
promotes alternative sources of income that reduce the  vulnerability of households to falling below the poverty line. 
Access to electricity has substantial expenditure-reducing effects, which is particularly important for poor households. 
The poorest households in Viet Nam with access to electricity spend less than 2% of their total spending on electricity. 
This is low compared with other countries in the region. Reduced expenditure on electricity allows households to use 
more expenditure for food and education and health services. Access to electricity also reduces the workload of 
women in food processing and collecting water. Irrigation using electricity reduces input cost for farmers and increases 
agricultural productivity. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
The poverty analysis for the Project was conducted to identify issues and assess impacts on the sector level since it 
was difficult to identify specific end-beneficiaries. Field assessments and consultations were conducted in both rural 
and urban areas within the impact area of the Project. This was supplemented by data analysis from the 2002 Viet 
Nam Living Standard survey (VLSS 2002) and Electricity of Vietnam (EVN) consumption and connection cost data. A 
review of EVN’s business practices was conducted to identify possible barriers for the poor to connect. These were 
then discussed with the poor themselves and with the provincial people’s committees in the project areas. 
 
VLSS 2002 shows that the national incidence of poverty has been reduced from 37% to 29%. Poverty headcounts in 
the provinces located in the Project area ranges form 47.7% in Nge An  to 15.2% in Hanoi. The share of poor 
households reported to use electricity as a main source of lighting in the project areas ranges from 75% to 95%. The 
ratio of rural to urban beneficiaries is about 1:4. This means that the majority of project benefits will accrue to urban 
areas where poverty incidences are generally lower. But with strong rural-urban links, increasing urban migration 
(particularly of females who make up an increasing proportion of migrants), and remittances, indirect impacts in terms 
of employment and income effects of the Project are expected to benefit poor households in rural areas. Reducing 
unemployment and underemployment in both rural and urban areas will be key for sustaining the poverty reduction 
effects of economic growth. Formal sector employment opportunities need to be expanded to absorb new entrants into 
the labor market. 
 
The high share of households reported to use electricity as a main source of lighting suggests that a majority of the 
poor are connected. It can be assumed that the remaining households are the very poor and live either in very remote 
areas with no grid-access or far from the community center and the main grid. Special efforts will be needed to 
connect these households in terms of investments, management of local networks and in terms of addressing 
affordability, in particular that of up-front charges. Some donor funded programs exist that address up-front charges. 
But they are limited to specific project areas. 
 
The level of electricity consumption is normally strongly correlated with income. This is mainly because as household 
incomes rise, affordability of appliances increases. Poor households thus consume smaller amounts than nonpoor. 
The very poor are often limited to using one or two light bulbs and sometimes a fan. Consumption levels range from

low consumption levels, electricity is a priority for poor households. This is reflected in the fact that they are willing to
